The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.p:
❧Such as are deſirous, eyther themſelues to learne, or to haue theyr children or ſeruants inſtructed in any of theſe Artes and Faculties heere vnder named. It may pleaſe them to repayre vnto the houſe of Humfry Baker, dwellin • on the Northſide of the Royall Exchange, next adioyning to the ſigne of the ſhippe. Where they ſhall find the profeſſors of the ſaid Artes. &c. Readie to doe their ••
ligent endeuours for a reaſonable conſideration. Alſo if any be minded to haue their children boorded at the ſaid houſe, for the ſpeedier expedition of their learning they ſhall be well and reſonablie vſed, to theyr contentation.

div.head: ❧The Artes and Faculties to be taught, are theſe.
div.p:
Arithmeticke vulgar, namelie
Numeration.
Addition.
Subſtraction.
Multiplication.
Diuiſion.
Progreſſion.
In
Whole numbers.
Fractions both Arithmetical and Aſtronomicall.

The application of t ••… in operatiō, that is to ſay.
The rule of 4. nūbers proportionall.
The rule of 5. numbers or more.
The rule of gaine & loſſe with time.
The rules of barter both ſimple and compounde.
The rules of fellowſhippe without time, and with time.
The rules of intereſt both ſimple & compound.
The rule of Allegation.
The Virgins rule.
The rule of ſuppoſitions, commonmonly called falſe poſitions.
In
Whole numbers.
Fractions.
With
The extraction of all kinds of rootes of numbers.
Numeration. Proportions.
Addition Proportions.
Substraction. Proportions.
Multiplicatiō, & Proportions.
Diuiſion of Proportions.

The like in Surde, and Coſſick numbers with the application of them in the rule of Aequation.
For Queſtions Arithmeticall &
Geometricall.
And alſo
The ſecond quantities.
Of Algeber.

How to meaſure
Landes, Woods, and all other platformes whatſoeuer, and to reduce the ſame platformes into greater or leſſer ſhape, at your owne pleaſure.
Tymber, Stone, and all kinde of Solide bodies what ſoeuer.

The principles of
Geometrie, to be applyed to the ayde of all Mechanicall worke-men.

The vſe of the
Quadrant. The calculatiō of the Tables of Sinus, & Chords. With theyr proper vſe.
Geometricall ſquare, and Baculus Iacob. The calculatiō of the Tables of Sinus, & Chords. With theyr proper vſe.

The compoſition of the
Aſtronomers ſtaffe. With theyr vſes. The calculatiō of the Tables of Sinus, & Chords. With theyr proper vſe.
Aſtrolabie, and Ruler of Ptolomie. With theyr vſes. The calculatiō of the Tables of Sinus, & Chords. With theyr proper vſe.

p.hi: Alſo the perfect order how to keepe any accounts by Debitor and Creditor, after a more plaine manner then hath héeretofore béen vſually taught by any man within this Cittie.

Likewiſe how to rectifie, and make perfect any difficult or intricate account, depending in variance betwéene two, or more partners, and thereby to ſhewe, which of them ſhall be indebted the one to the other.

div.head: ❧ An account of foure Partners, to be rectified and made perfect by the order of Debitor and Creditor, as followeth.
div.p: Foure Merchants entred into Partnership, that is to ſay, A. B. C. and D. with this condition following.

list.item: A. Should keepe account of their dooings in companie, at London.
B. Should keepe account of their dooings in companie, at Roane.
C. Should keepe account of their dooings in companie, at Midleborow.
D. Should keepe account of their dooings in companie, at Elbing.

div.p: FIrſt A. at London layde into ſtocke for his aduenture in partnerſhip, 60. fine Kentiſh Clothes, which coſt him 15 .l. the Cloth the firſt pennie, and he payd for charges at the ſhipping of them forth to all places, 34 .l. 05 .s. 0 .d. ſter. Which riſeth to 11 .s. 5 .d. for euery Cloth.

list.item: Whereof the ſaid A. ſhypped to B. at Roan. 10. Clothes. Which coſt with charges .155. l .14. s .2. d.
More, he ſhipped to C. at Midleborow, 30. Clothes. Which coſt with charges .467. l .02. s .6. d.
And he ſhipped vnto D. at Elbing, 20. Clothes. Which coſt with charges .311 . l .08. s .4. d.

div.p: THE account of B. at Roane is thus, after he had receiued the ſaid 10. Clothes, he payd for fraight, cuſtome, & other charges there, the ſum of 15. franks .10. ſoulz .6. deniers tornois. And he ſold them at 60. Crownes of the ſonne the Cloth, which amounteth to 600. Crownes. And he ſent home to A. at London, foure truſſes of Roane Canuas, contayning 140. péeces, béeing aulnes 5700. meaſure of Roane, which coſt 57. franks, 12. ſoulz .6. deniers tornois the 100. Aulnes. Amounteth to the ſum of 3284. franks, 12. ſoulz .6. deniers tornois. For which he paid charges cléere aboord the ſhyp, 25. franks .15. ſoulz. tornois.

The account of C. at Midleborow is thus: After he had receiued the ſaid 30. Clothes, he paid for fraight, cuſtome, and other, carriages there, the ſum of 02. l .15 . s .6. d. flemiſh. And he ſold thē at 27. l .10. s. flemiſh the Cloth, which amounteth to • 75. l. flemiſh And he ſent home to A. at London, 6. cheſts of Holland Cloth, contayning 240. péeces, beeing 5760. Ells flemiſh, which coſt 3. s .4. d. flemiſh, the eſt flemiſh, amounteth to 960. l. flemiſh. For the which he paid charges cléere aboord the ſhyp, 31. l .16. s. flemiſh. More, the ſaid C. ſent to A. at London, 4. Caſes of veluets, containing 24. peeces, béeing 1000. flemiſh ells, which coſt 13. s .4. d. flemiſh the ell, amounteth to 666. l .13. s .4. d. flemiſh, and he paid for charges of them cléere aboord the Shyp. 21. l .6. s .8. d. flemiſh.

The account of D. at Elbing is thus. After he had receiued the 20. Clothes, he payd for cuſtome, fraight, and other charges there, the ſumme of 126. florins. And he ſolde them there at 105. florins the Cloth, which amounteth to 2100. florins. And he ſent home to A. at London, 42. Laſt of Flaxe of Quinsborow weight, which coſt 50. groſhe the ſtone, amounteth to the ſumme of 4200. florins. For the which he paid charges cléere aboord the ſhyp. 136. florins.

The account of A. at London, for all the goods returned home from all places, ſtandeth thus. He receiued the 4. truſſes Canuas from Roane, and payd for charges, 13. l .05. s .00. d. ſterling. More, he receiued the 6. Cheſts of Holland Cloth from Midleborow, and paid for charges. 49. l .00. 00. More, hee receiued the 4. Caſes of Veluet from thence, and payd for charges. 34. l .15. s .00. More, he receiued from Elbing the 42. Laſt of Flaxe, and paid for charges. 96. l .17. s .6. d. ſterling.

The ſaid A. ſold the 5700. Aulnes Canuas at 6. l .13. s .4. d. the 100. Aulnes, amounts to 380. l .00.0. ſterling. He ſold ye 5760. ells flemiſh of Hollande Cloth, at 7. s .6. d. the Engliſh ell, amounteth to 1296. l .00.0. ſterling. More, he ſold the 1000. flemiſh ells of Veluet, at 22. s. the Engliſh yarde, amounts to 825. l .00.0. ſter. And he ſold the 42. Laſt of Flaxe, accounting 18. C. weight to euery Laſt, at 32. s. the C. is 1209. l .12. s .0. ſterling.

This doone, the Partners B. C. and D. repaire to London, to make vp their accounts, and beeing agreed betweene themſelues, that euery Partner ſhall beare his own charges at the place where he kept his account. The queſtion is to know, whether they haue gained or loſt by theyr ſaid traffique, and how much each Partner muſt haue of the gayne, if any gaine be? or to beare of the loſſe, if any loſſe be? according to each mans ſtock, that he ſhall be found to haue layde in. And further, if any of them bee in debt, which of them ſhall be indebted, the one to the other, and how much? Alwaies prouided, that the moneys of the three Forraine Countries, ſhal be vallued as followeth, viz. Euery 5. florins of Elbing, ſhall be rated to be worth, 20. ſhillings ſterling, and 20. ſhillings ſterling, ſh ••• be valued at 31. ſhil. 7. pence flemiſh, and euerie Crowne of the ſonne of three francks the Crowne, ſhall be valued to be worth 6. ſhillings 3. pence ſterling.
